dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera is stationary as the fade comes in: through a tangle of brush can be seen in the night, four dark figures, one of them carrying a lantern. They are evidently searching for something. They come toward camera through a garden long neglected ... gone into ruin As they reach foreground the camera moves with them. They are men of the English servant class: a gardener and some hostlers. The gardener; who carries the lantern searches the ground ahead of them as they stumble forward, frightened. It isn't a job that they relish.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A Newcomb shot of the house of the English country type i a state of decay quite as sad as that of the garden. Windows are broken, shutters loose; it is bleak, desolate The dim figures of the men with their lantern are approaching from b. g. a corner of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men coming into scene, stop suddenly, startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP, a shutter hanging loose on rusty hinges, banging back and forth in a gust of wind. BACK TO SCENE: The men as they shudder. One of them tryin to conquer the fear that holds them, points up, telling them it was only a shutter in the wind. The gardener with the lantern indicates for them to press forward. They sta around the corner of the house. 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around corner, lying crumpled, still and lifeless in f.g. is the body of a man. The men come around the corner with the lantern. They stop short in horror. The man with the lantern leans over the body. The others huddle with scare faces around him.  3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men, with the body below frame line. The gardener, holding the lantern so that he can see, looks down and ou of scene as though at the face of the dead man. He looks at the others and says in an awed whisper:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "It's ‘im. It's 'arry Balfour" BACK TO SCENE: The men look at each other in awe. One of them shakes his head slowly and says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "This'll break 'is sister Lucy's 'eart" BACK TO SCENE. There is solemn assent to this.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "And 'ow about Sir James? Him as loved 'em both like they was 'is own children." BACK TO SCENE: Again there is solemn assent.

dialogues.speaker: QUICK FADE IN
dialogues.text: A Newcomb shot of another English country house, this one with lighted windows and well-kept grounds, a distinct contrast to the ruin just seen. Run only a few feet for swift, impressionistic effect and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again the sense of contrast. Here are warmth, wealth, comfort. Seated at a piano is Lucy Balfour, a pretty Engl girl in her early twenties. Standing listening to her, as she plays, is Sir James Hamlin, a dignified, kindly count gentleman in his late forties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy and Sir James, as she finishes playing and looks up him with a wistful smile. He indicates for her to play something more. She selected a piece and is startled when little worried look crosses her face and she looks up at him and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I simply can't understand, Sir James, why Harry went away without saying anything."

dialogues.speaker: INT HAMLIN MUSIC ROOM, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: Lucy as she finishes title, a pretty puzzlement in her expression. It is apparent that she is not greatly worrie just perplexed. 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James, as he smiles down at her gravely, a deep affection in his eyes, and says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: “There is nothing to worry about, Lucy, my dear."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two at the piano, as Sir James finishes reaching over and patting Lucy's hand affectionately. After a moment sh resumes her playing. He stands watching her, then turns thoughtfully and goes out of scene. 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By arched entrance to hall, as Sir James comes thoughtful in and pulls a long bell-cord. A butler enters. With a lo off toward Lucy, Sir James gives a quiet order to the butler.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Have my secretary come here." BACK TO SCENE: The butler exits. Sir James looks again of toward Lucy. In a moment his secretary enters -- a young man of the serious type, a student. Sir James asks him quietly:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Any word, Mr. Hibbs?" BACK TO SCENE: Hibbs is about to answer, but looks off toward Lucy and then gets over in pantomime that perhaps they had better step into the hall. Sir James nods. They exit.  9.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other side of doorway as Sir James and Hibbs come in. Now Hibbs tells him earnestly:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "I insisted, sir, on their searching the grounds over at the old Balfour place--" BACK TO SCENE: Sir James nods gravely to this, indicating that the secretary acted wisely, that that was the right thing to do. Hibbs goes on.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: “Weird things have happened there in the last five years-- ever since Miss Lucy's father--" BACK TO SCENE: Sir James checks him with a gesture. Both look off sharply down the hall. 10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A maid, Miss Smithson, is standing at an open door, stari out and down in horror. She screams, drawing back. 11

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James and Hibbs, staring. They run out. 12

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy. She stops playing, listens in sudden fright, then rises and exits. 13

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At door, Sir James, Hibbs, Miss Smithson, the gardener an a hostler. The gardener and the hostler are just straightening up from having placed below frames line in f.g. the body of the dead Harry Balfour. Sir James, leani over, straightens up gravely. The body is not seen. 14

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At entrance to music room, as Lucy comes through, looks o screams and starts forward. 15

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At door, as before, as Lucy comes in from down the hall, staring in horror at the body out of scene. “Harry! Harry she cries. Sir James put an arm about her comfortingly fo  a moment, leading her away a little, indicating for the maid to take her away. Miss Smithson leads Lucy out of scene. Sir James turns and gives an order to the butler, who exits quickly. Sir James turns to the hostler and others and gives orders. Hibbs, looking off after Lucy, exits in that direction. Sir James starts quickly up the stairs. 16

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy, on a couch, being comforted by the maid. Hibbs come slowly in, standing for a moment looking at them. At a gesture from Hibbs, the maid quickly withdraws. Hibbs sit on the couch beside Lucy. 17

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs and Lucy, as he sits on the couch beside her. She i staring off with tragic face. Hibbs feels terribly about all. He would like to be able to speak a consoling word t her, but he does not know just what to say or how to say Hesitatingly, he says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Miss Balfour, I----- " BACK TO SCENE: She turns away to the end of the couch and bursts into uncontrollable sobbing. Hibbs sits and looks her with the deepest sympathy and a sort of pathetic helplessness.

dialogues.speaker: FADE OUT
dialogues.text: [Scenes 18 through 51 OMITTED]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP (NIGHT) a broken shutter with broken window pane. A bat fluttering against the pane. The shutter bangs in a gust of wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two men are seen dimly, standing under a tree. A jaunting cart is driving slowly in, with the gardener and Miss Smithson. The cart stops as they look off towards the house. (The cart is loaded with trunks, baggage.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grand Staircases. Coming down the stairs are two figures, man and a woman. The man, who carries a lamp, is as stran a creature as the eyes ever beheld. He wears a black beav hat and a black Inverness coat and his face has on it the pallor of death. There is, indeed, something not of this Earth in his appearance. Nor is the woman with him less strange. Her face also is of an unearthly pallor. She is garbed all in black, with long black sleeves to her cloak that look like wings. They come the long walk down the stairs. He hands the lamp to the woman. No word is spoken between them. She starts off toward a side room. The man goes slowly toward the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jaunting cart in f.g., the two men at side under a tr A light passes a downstairs window. The Man in the Beaver Hat comes out the front door. The gardener suddenly whips his steed and the cart goes out of scene pellmell. 53

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men under the tree, two business-like Britishers, one of whom has a legal document in his hand. The Man in Beaver Hat enters to them. One of the two men says to him

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "You'll pardon us, sir, for not going in with you, but..." BACK TO SCENE: He shudders a little, expressively. THE MA IN THE BEAVER HAT indicates the legal document without speaking. The other man unfolds it. The Man in the Beaver Hat takes out a fountain pen, indicating that he will sig The first man tells him:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: “Understand, sir, the owner will make no repairs.” BACK TO SCENE: The Man in the Beaver Hat nods solemnly to this and, without speaking, leans over and starts to sign the document. The two look at him curiously, drawing back from him a little, instinctively. 54

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jaunting cart with the gardener and maid driving pellmell in, around the driveway, toward rear of house. 55

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, the secretary, is giving some orders to the butler  Two or three other servants are present. Run a few feet. Then the rear door is flung open and Miss Smithson, the maid, comes excitedly in, starting at once to tell the secretary and butler what she saw at the Balfour House. T gardener follows. He nods a pop-eyed assent to everything the maid is telling. Everybody present is much impressed, including Hibbs, the secretary, who starts to question Mi Smithson. Suddenly all stop, tense, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU bell indicator on wall. Bell is ringing. An arrow has dropped, indicating from what room. BACK TO SCENE: There is a sigh of relief. It was only a call for the butler. He exits. Hibbs asks a couple of mor suggestions of Miss Smithson, then follows the butler out 56

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James and chauffeur. The chauffeur is closing the doo depositing Sir James' bag on the floor as the butler come in. He is helping Sir James off with his coat as Hibbs, t secretary, comes in. The Butler takes the coat and bag an is about to start out with them when a ring is heard at t front door. The butler puts down the bag and coat and ope the front door, admitting the two agents seen under the tree at the Balfour house. Sir James at the door to the library, turns in some surprise. One of the agents, holdi up the lease, tells him:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "It's about a tenant, sir, for the old Balfour place." BACK TO SCENE: "A tenant?" Sir James is really surprised. He indicates for the two men to step into the library. Th do so, followed by Hibbs. 57

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James goes to desk and sits down. The agent hands him the lease. Hibbs stands at one side, in case he might be needed. Sir James unfolds the document. One of the agents says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "I told him, sir, you'd make no repairs."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At desk, as the agent finishes title. Sir James nods that that was the right thing to do. Now, with the lease unfolded, he scans down it with a business-like eye. Suddenly he frowns, staring in astonishment down at the document.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Signature on lease:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James, staring down at the signature. He looks up, hi lips forming the name: “Roger Balfour!" He looks up slowl Then, indicating the signature with a forefinger, he says slowly:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "This is the name of the man who committed suicide in that house five years ago!" BACK TO SCENE: He finishes title, in awe and wonder. 60

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two agents, staring in astonishment. 61

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, the secretary, as he says, involuntarily:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Lucy's father!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of group as they stare at each other. 63

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At front door. The butler is opening the door. Burke of Scotland Yard, with a bag, stands there.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Tell Sir James an old friend -- just back from India -- has come  to visit him." BACK TO SCENE: Burke comes in; The butler closes the door and exits toward the library. 64

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group as before. The butler, stepping in from the entrance hall, gives Sir James the Message. “An old friend?" Sir James says, trying to recall who it might be and then, “Show him in." The butler exits. After a moment he returns with Burke. Sir James rises from the desk. The stand looking at each other for a moment, then Sir James comes forward and they greet each other with the warmth a cordiality of old friends long parted. Sir James then tur to the others and says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Colonel Yates, gentlemen"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of group as Sir James finishes title. The introduction is acknowledged with a bow, in which Burke allows his gaze t rest in rather long scrutiny on Hibbs, the secretary, so that the young man is beginning to be uncomfortable. Sir James, picking up the lease, turns with it to Burke, with a return of his excitement of a moment ago. 66

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James and Burke, as Sir James tells him swiftly of th name signed to the lease. Burke smiles dryly and says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "A coincidence, Sir James -- it could be nothing more." BACK TO SCENE: This is what Sir James wants to believe an is relieved when Burke says it. Burke turns to the two agents out of scene and says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "I knew Roger Balfour well. What did this man look like?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Group as Burke finishes question. The two agents exchange look. Then one of them says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “That's hard to say, sir. There was something weird about him -- that made you feel creepy --"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two agents as the first one finishes title in awe. Th other one goes on:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: “Something like he wasn't of this Earth.... something unholy--" BACK TO SCENE: He finishes title. The other nods in agreement to this. 69

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke, looking out of scene at them for a moment with penetrating glance. Then he laughs and says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Nonsense!" 70

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of group, as Burke finishes title, laughing. Sir James is now a bit more at ease, but still nervous and upset. The two agents look shamefaced and foolish. One of them gets over to Sir James and says that if they are not needed an more they'll be going. Sir James nods goodnight to them, turning and indicating to Hibbs to show them out. Hibbs exits with the two agents. Sir James sinks into his seat the desk. Burke draws up a chair. 71

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James and Burke at the desk as Burke sits down. Sir James stares for a moment, frowning at the signature on t lease. Then, with a sudden thought, he rummages in a draw of the desk and gets out a packet of papers. With nervous fingers, he slips the rubber band off and examines the signature attached. He places this beside the other and shows the two of them to Burke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two signatures, "Roger Balfour", along side each other. They very closely resemble each other.  BACK TO SCENE: The two men look up from the document seriously. For a moment, not a word is spoken between the Then Sir James says, in awe:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "The signatures are the same!" BACK TO SCENE: Burke nods solemnly. "Yes." 72

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is dark, except for a shaft of moonlight from th window. In this moonlight, Lucy, pale and beautiful in a white dress, stands looking out into the garden. Hibbs enters to her. She does not turn for a moment. Hibbs stan looking at her for a moment, worried. Then he speaks to h softly. She turns, startled. Then, seeing it is Hibbs, sh says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "I thought I heard a voice calling to me from the garden -- ever so softly: 'Lucy--'" BACK TO SCENE: Hibbs stares at her for a moment, then tur and looks out into the garden. He turns back to her, closing the casement window and tells her:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: “There s no one there -- You're nervous, dear-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK TO SCENE: He finishes title. She smiles wanly. "Yes, I'm nervous." He turns and starts to close the windows. 73

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James and Burke, as Sir James talks to him, earnestly Burke, with a cynical smile, interrupts, saying:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "you mean a ghost, Sir James?" BACK TO SCENE: Sir James shakes his head, solemnly. They look at each other for a moment, then Sir James answers:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Not a ghost, no! Worse than that--"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James, finishes title, rises and takes down two or th ancient looking books from the bookcases that line the walls. He puts these on the desk, opens one of them, find @ passage and shows it to Burke. 75

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs and Lucy, as Hibbs turns on a light switch by the door to hall and the room is flooded with light. They go over and sit down on a settee, as he talks to her serious 76

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James and Burke at desk, as Burke looks up from passa he was reading and says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "We're not living in the Middle Ages, Sir James." CUT TO SCENE: Sir James is deeply thoughtful. He ponders this for a moment, then says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Just the same, I'd like to have a look at the vault where Roger Balfour was buried!" BACK TO SCENE. He finishes title. They sit looking at eac other solemnly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Newcomb shot, weird, eerie; bare-limbed, queer trees; i semi f.g. a mausoleum. Run a few feet for the effect and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The open door of the mausoleum. Sir James and Burke stagg backward out the door of the mausoleum. Burke has a pocke flashlight in his hand. He clicks it off. They stare at each other aghast. Then Sir James mutters, incredulously, in horror:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “The coffin was empty!" BACK TO SCENE: He finishes title. Burke nods slowly, solemnly. Suddenly Sir James clutches at Burke's arm and both men are tense, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP owl on bare limb of tree. It opens its beak.

dialogues.speaker: "HOO
dialogues.text: BACK TO INSERT: It closes beak. BACK TO SCENE: Sir James, trembling, gets over "Let's get out of here." Burke looks up and off, telling him: "It's only an owl." They turn to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house and the ruined garden in weird lighting. At the gate stand the Man in the Beaver Hat, the girl in black with the sleeves that look like wings. These two are welcoming three others -- three men as queer in appearanc as the man in the Beaver Hat and his companion. Not a wor is spoken. The whole effect is odd, fantastic. They start toward the house, slowly, in solemn procession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vignetted passage of the printed page of an old book, the paper of a parchment-like quality, aged, the print in an Old English type: “--the undead, the vampyrs: dead bodies which leave their graves at night to suck the blood of the living."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, Sir James and Burke. The Secretary is reading from one of the old books to the other two men. Both of whom seem to be profoundly impressed. He turns the page and is instantly struck by what he encounters there. He spreads the book open on the desk and calls their attention to i They lean over, seeing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAGE illustrating from book done in old wood-cut fashion depicting a vampire.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR HAMLIN LIBRARY, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: Sir James and Burke, looking down at the illustration. Burke looks up from it, in his eyes the faintest suggesti of a cynical smile. Sir James looks at the page facing th illustration and reads on for a few lines. There is a strange excitement in his manner as he indicates to Burke to read what he has just read. Burke looks down at the page:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Extract from book: "Men who have died by suicide frequently become vampyrs. They come out of their graves at night, rush upon people sleeping in their beds--" BACK TO SCENE: Burke looks up from the page. Sir James sa to him slowly, with deep significance:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Roger Balfour died a suicide!"

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR LIBRARY, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: Sir James, as he finishes title, awed, looking out of sce at Burke. 82

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR LIBRARY, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: Burke, as he realizes the significance of this. There is moment when he seems deeply impressed. Then, with a sudde change of manner, he says, vehemently:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "My God, man, this is the twentieth century -- and here we are almost believing atin

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR LIBRARY, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: The three men, as Burke finishes title, indicating the bo on the table. Hibbs tells him rather hotly:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "T believe it!" BACK TO SCENE: Burke turns a cold gaze on Hibbs. For a moment it seems as if his eyes would bore through the secretary. Then, with something of contempt in his final appraisement, he turns to Sir James, who shrugs his shoulders, as though to get over, "What can we believe?" Suddenly all three are tense, listening. Burke says in a whisper:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "What was that?" BACK TO SCENE: They listen, tense, not moving a muscle. Suddenly Hibbs cries out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "A scream -- a woman's scream!

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR LIBRARY, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: The three men, as Hibbs finishes title, indicating upward The three men rush out through the door to the hall. 85

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR HAMLIN HALL, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: The three men running out from the library, run to the stairs. As they start up,

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR UPPER HALL, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: The three men coming into scene up the stairs. They stop f.g., listening, tense. Hibbs cries out, pointing off tow a door, wildly--

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "It's from Lucy's room!" BACK TO SCENE: They rush over to the door indicated.  87

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR UPPER HALL, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: At door to Lucy's room as Hibbs, first in, tries the door It is locked. He pounds upon the door. "Lucy! Lucy!" "Bre it open!" commands Sir James in wild excitement. 88

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR LUCY'S ROOM, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: Miss Smithson, the maid, is backing away toward the door. She has her hand clutched to her throat and is staring in terror out of scene. She hears the hammering on the door. She reaches the door, frantically turns the key. The door is flung open. Hibbs, Sir James and Burke plunge into the room. The maid has her hand to her throat in pain. They stop, looking around the room out of scene. Sir James cries out:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Where's Lucy?" BACK TO SCENE: Taking a hand from her throat, Miss Smiths points wildly off saying:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I -- locked her in there- BACK TO SCENE: Sir James and Hibbs rush out, Miss Smithso sinking into a chair. 89

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR LUCY'S ROOM, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: Door to dressing room. Sir James, Hibbs, rushing in. Hibb turns the key in the door. Lucy, weak and faint from fright, steps out. Sir James puts an arm about her, supporting her. Speaking comfortingly to her, he starts o with her toward an open window, out of scene. Hibbs looks off after them, deep concern in his eyes. 90

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR LUCY'S ROOM, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: By open window. Sir James, leading in Lucy, seats her by the open window, leaning over her, speaking comfortingly her. In response to a question, she assures him that she all right. He looks up and off, as though spoken to out o scene. 91

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR LUCY'S ROOM, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: Burke leaning over Miss Smithson, whose throat is exposed He has evidently been looking at her neck. He is calling off to Sir James. Hibbs comes in from the dressing room door. Sir James enters from the window. Burke leans over and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU neck, with two small wounds, from which blood is trickling slowly. BACK TO SCENE: Sir James looks up slowly, gravely. He indicates for Hibbs to look. The secretary does so. He looks up and he and Sir James stare at each other for a solemn moment. "Well?" says Burke. Sir James tells him:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Those are the marks found on the neck of young Harry Balfour." BACK TO SCENE: Burke nods. He thought so. Turning to Miss Smithson, he says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Tell us what happened." BACK TO SCENE: Miss Smithson puts a handkerchief to her throat, covering the wound, and says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Miss Lucy was getting ready for bed. I went down to the linen closet--"

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR LUCY'S ROOM, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: Miss Smithson, as she pauses, then goes on talking. As sh talks,

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR UPPER HALL, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: In f.g. Miss Smithson is getting bath towels from the lin closet. Around a turn in the hall in b.g., walking slowly toward her, comes the Man in the Beaver Hat. She does not see him for a moment. He is midway down to her, when she looks up, sees him and runs.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR LUCY'S ROOM, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: Miss Smithson, fright in her eyes at the recollection of She gulps, then goes on:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "I ran in here,  locked the door." BACK TO SCENE: She goes on talking.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR LUCY'S ROOM, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: Miss Smithson, locking door, turns, hurries Lucy into the dressing room, locks that door, then turns staring at the door to the hall. 93

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR LUCY'S ROOM, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: Miss Smithson, staring in horror as she sees: 94

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR LUCY'S ROOM, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: On door, a vapor starts to come through the keyhole.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR LUCY'S ROOM, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: Miss Smithson open-mouthed, eyes bulging, as she draws ba in terror, staring out of scene toward the door. 96

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR LUCY'S ROOM, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: at door. The vapor coming through the keyhole forms itsel into the shape of a man. The vapor slowly disappears and, standing there, is the Man in the Beaver Hat. He starts forward. THE CAMERA MOVES WITH HIM until backed against the bed, Miss Smithson comes into scene. The Man the Beaver Hat seizes her and puts his teeth against her neck.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR LUCY'S ROOM, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: Miss Smithson talking as she says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "I screamed. Maybe for a minute I fainted. He was gone."

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR LUCY'S ROOM, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: Miss Smithson, Sir James, Burke and Hibbs as she finishes title, sinking back in the chair all but overcome. There a profound silence for a moment upon the three men. Then Burke says to Sir James calmly:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "This is a case of nerves --  of hysteria -- of overwrought imagination-- BACK TO SCENE: There is no response from Sir James or Hibbs. Sir James indicates the wound in the neck. "How do you account for that?" They all turn, sharply, looking of toward Lucy at the window. 98

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR LUCY'S ROOM, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: Lucy at window. She is rising from her chair, staring out the window and down toward the garden, a little cry of fe on her lips. 99

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunning down from Lucy's angle. The Man in the Beaver Hat going softly away from camera through the trees. 100

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy as Sir James and Burke crowd in staring off and down seeing: 101

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continuation of previous scene with the Man in the Beaver Hat disappearing behind some brush toward the garden wall reappearing again, going out the gate. 102

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy, Sir James and Burke staring out and down. Sir James cries out:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "By God, that's not imagination!" BACK TO SCENE: He finishes title, clutching Burke's arm, pointing wildly off. Lucy draws back out of picture. Burk and Sir James turn and stare at each other. Burke, with a nod of his head, indicating for Sir James to follow, turn out of scene. 103

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke leads the way out of the room for Sir James. Lucy Hibbs and Miss Smithson stand staring off after them, as in a momentary daze, held in the spell of the recent amazing adventure. 104

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke and Sir James, as Sir James closes the door behind him. Burke says to him crisply:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Sir James, two pair of eyes are better than one--" BACK TO SCENE: Sir James looks at him, only half guessing his meaning, getting over: "I saw it, too!" Burke says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "We'll have a look at the old Balfour House."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke finishes title, Sir James nods in solemn acquiescen They start out down the stairs. Miss Smithson comes out t door, looks off a moment after them, fearfully, then exit in the opposite direction, down the hall. 106

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy and Hibbs as Hibbs closes the casement window and locks it tight, then turns toward her solicitously. 107

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a corner or jog in the hall, Miss Smithson stopping, looks back for a moment, then peering around the corner fearfully, she exits around the corner. 108

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs and Lucy, as Hibbs makes her comfortable in easy chair, trying to calm her, although it is quite evident that if one of them is excited, it is Hibbs. He tells her

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Now, we mustn't get nervous or excited--" BACK TO SCENE: And he proceeds to knock over a vase which causes him far more alarm than it does Lucy. 109

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the servants attached to the house-hold are huddled together. It is evident that they have heard the screams, that the night's fear is upon them. Miss Smithson enterin her hand to her throat, sinks into a chair, weakly glad t have attained this haven of human company. They crowd around her. 110

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Smithson and group of servants, as she starts to tel them the story of the attack. Working up to her subject, rises, enacting the horrible scene. They draw back, agape eyes popping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A row of pans under a sink. A black cat walks under the pans, knocking one of them down with a clatter. The cat leaps out of scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: lil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire group, in a highly-strung state of nerves from Miss Smithson's narrative, jumps away from her wildly at the clatter of the pans -- a FLASH. 112

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The groom backs against a hot stove -- FLASH 113

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On wall shelf -- the cat leaps up and in, knocking over some glass jars -- FLASH 114

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLASH: the room in a panic, running into each other, tryi to get out of the way of they know not what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cat leaps off the shelf-- 116

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Smithson, as the cat lands on her head -- she lets o an unearthly scream-- 117

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs and Lucy. They hear the scream! "There it is again! His first thought is for Lucy's safety. He rushes to the door, locks it then listens, tense. 118

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place a wreck -- chairs overturned, people on the flo -- crawling under the table -- any place for safety. 119

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A faint light flickers from the upper windows. The place weird, ghostly. Approaching the gate are Burke and Sir James. They stop at the gate. Run a few feet for the mood of the scene. Burke and Sir James step softly over to the shelter of a tree. 120

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke and Sir James, under a tree. A deadly solemnity is upon them both. They look up toward the upper windows. Si James clutches Burke's arm as they see: 121

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR UPPER ROOM BALFOUR HOUSE, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: Through broken window pane, a shadow is thrown on the ceiling of a giant bat flying slowly. 122

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR BALFOUR HOUSE, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: Burke and Sir James under the tree. The two men turn and exchange a look. Burke indicates the tree, getting over i whispered pantomime that they must see what is with in th upper room. Burke starts from a low branch to climb the tree. He goes up out of scene. Sir James stares off and u at the house for a moment, then with a firm decision to s it through, starts to climb the tree. 123

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke coming into position in the upper branches of the tree. He looks off toward the house seeing: 124

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Framed through broken window. Sitting facing the window i one of the men shown arriving earlier one of those welcom at the gate by the Man in Beaver Hat and his strange woma companion. He is watching with profound interest what appears to be a giant bat flying slowly near the ceiling. This comes into better view and it is seen to have the fa of the Girl in Black. Sitting with his back to the scene is the Man in the Beaver Hat. 125

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke staring off. Sir James coming into scene up the tre He waits until Sir James is in position and then indicate gravely off. Sir James sees: 126

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another cut of the scene with the Bat Girl flying slowly. But the stranger facing the window doesn't watch her any more. He sits tense, listening, as though he might have heard them in the tree. 127

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James staring, a strange excitement in his eyes. 128

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scene as before for a very few feet. Then it:

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVES QUICKLY INTO
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP the Stranger, listening tensely. There is a bulle wound in his temple. On his face is a deathlike pallor, b his eyes are tense, alert. 129

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James, staring. He licks his lips with a dry tongue, then reaches over and touches Burke's hand in scene. 130

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke and Sir James as Burke turns to him coolly. Sir Jam indicates off, whispering hoarsely:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "The man sitting facing us is Roger Balfour!" BACK TO SCENE: Burke looks at him searchingly for a momen then off toward the house. Sir James follows his gaze, fascinated. 131

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stranger, as he grows more tense, listening now as though he were certain he heard something. 132

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James and Burke. Sir James is in such a state of nervous excitement now that when he pantomimes: "Let's ge down out of here." Burke nods assent. Sir James starts do Burke turns and looks off again toward the house. Then starts down after him. 133

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the tree, as Sir James lets himself to the ground, Burke following. Sir James starts immediately for the gat Burke stops a moment, then follows. 134

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At gate, as Sir James waits nervously looking off toward house. Burke comes softly in:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "That was Lucy's father. He shot himself in that house five years ago!" BACK TO SCENE: Burke frowns, shaking his head slowly, sti the doubter, as though it couldn't be. Sir James, ina terrible state of mind, insists:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Did you see the bullet hole in his temple?" 135

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James as he finishes title, a fever amounting almost a mania, in his eyes. 136

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke profoundly thoughtful says, "Yes," then--

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Frankly, Sir James, I am baffled."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both, as Burke finishes title, Sir James urges him in whispered pantomime to come away from the accursed place. Burke looks off toward the house, then says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "There is nothing we can do but take every precaution -- and wait." BACK TO SCENE: They start out. 138

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men go out over the sideline. As soon as they hav gone, the figure of the Stranger who was identified as Lucy's father, appears at an upstairs window. The long sh is weird, ghostly. The Stranger opens the broken window, peering out into the night. 139

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At window as the Stranger opens the window, peering out. calls softly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Lucy....Lucy!" BACK TO SCENE: He finishes title, looking out as if he expected to see her. 140

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs and Lucy as he gets a comforter and a blanket and brings it down to her in her easy chair and leans over wi it, starting to wrap it around her. 141

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs and Lucy as he wraps the blanket around her, tellin her:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "There won't be much sleep in this house tonight." BACK TO SCENE: He sits down beside her as though to watch over her should she fall asleep. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: Morning 142

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old house, for the first time in the light of day. There is no sign of life about it; and somehow with its ruined garden and its broken windows, it is even more desolate than at night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Downstairs room. Sir James and Burke are coming down the stairs, slowly looking about them. They reach the foot of the stairs and stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke and Sir James, as Burke says to him:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Empty, every room -- empty." BACK TO SCENE: Sir James looks off around the great room. His gaze lifts toward the ceiling. He gives a start as h sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five bats huddled together, clinging to the ceiling, asleep. BACK TO SCENE: Sir James points. Burke looks. Then the tw men look at each other. Then Burke says quickly:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "I know what you're thinking -- don't say it." BACK TO SCENE: Burke looks off around the room, speculatively. Then he turns to Sir James and says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "This is the room in which Roger Balfour committed suicide?" BACK TO SCENE: Sir James tells him that it is. Burke asks

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Where was the body found?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke finishes question. Sir James steps over to a table, turns a chair a little to put it into the position in whi the body was found, then indicates a position on the floo as though the body has slouched out from the chair to the floor. Burke comes over to him. 144

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James as Burke comes into him. Burke looks down at th table, the chair, studying. Then he looks up and says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "I want you to tell me all you know about the circumstances." BACK TO SCENE: Sir James nods willingly. He says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "I came to see Roger Balfour earlier in that evening. It was about 8:30. I came in that door--"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James, finishing title, crosses and indicates a side door. He goes on telling the story of his visit, Burke listening intently. Sir James crosses to the table, Burke following. 146

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At table, as Sir James indicates a chair at the end of th table, saying:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Miss Lucy was here when I called. She was about thirteen -- hair down her back, a beautiful child--" BACK TO SCENE: Sir James sighs a little at the recollecti 147

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy and Hibbs coming into the garden. They go over to a pretty spot in the garden and Lucy sits down. Hibbs stand looking at her. 148

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James is finishing his story. Burke thanks him, looks at his watch and they exit. 149

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs and Lucy as he looks at her long and fondly, then says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "I want the right to protect you, Lucy--"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs as he finishes title, leaning over, his earnestness in his eyes. 151

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy as she looks up at him, wistfully. 152

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs as he says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "I know it's asking a lot -- since I've got my way to make in the world--"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both, as Hibbs finishes title. Her trust and her faith in him are in her eyes as she looks up at him. She says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "You'll make your way, too, Jerry--" BACK TO SCENE: She pauses, then rises and he takes her hands in his. They stand, look into each others eyes. Finally, she says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "You see, Jerry, I love you." BACK TO SCENE: He gathers her into his arms. 154

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke and Sir James turning in at the gate, slowly, thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy and Hibbs, in each other's arms, as they draw apart and Hibbs says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "I'll tell Sir James--" BACK TO SCENE: She protests:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "No, no, not yet, Jerry -- he has been so good and kind -- I wouldn't hurt him for the world--" BACK TO SCENE: She finishes title. 156

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another part of garden, as Sir James and Burke come in a stop. They look off seeing: 157

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs and Lucy, a beautiful shot, oblivious of everything but themselves as they stand facing each other. 158

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke and Sir James as Burke indicates off and says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Secretaries and servants sometimes talk too much--" BACK TO SCENE: Sir James frowns, looking curiously at Bur as though wondering if by any chance Burke suspects Hibbs the secretary. Burke says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Better dictate a letter to Scotland Yard, asking them to send four men for tonight." BACK TO SCENE: Sir James nods, then calls out of scene: "Mr. Hibbs." 159

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs and Lucy as they turn. Hibbs hearing himself called turns to Lucy. Quickly, she makes a signal of silence to him, getting over that he is not to tell Sir James. He no agreement and exits. She looks off after him fondly. 160

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke and Sir James, as Hibbs comes into them, Sir James gets over that he wants some work done and Hibbs and Sir James exit to the house. Burke looks off a moment toward Lucy, then exits toward her. 161

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy looking off expectantly. After a moment, Burke enter hat in hand. He stands for a moment, gravely looking at h Then he says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Miss Balfour, you don't know me....but whatever happens I want you to have complete trust in me!"  162

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke as he finishes title, gravely, looking out of scene at her. 163

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy, suddenly quite serious, staring at him out of scene 164

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke, as he studies her for a moment with grave eyes, th says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Mine is a hard life, Miss Balfour, cast in ways not always pleasant--"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke and Lucy, as he pauses, then goes on talking to her with growing interest. 166

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James dictating a letter to Hibbs, who is sitting a little distance from a window, his steno book on his knee Sir James pauses. Hibbs slides his chair over so that he can see out of the window. He looks out and sees: 167

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke, talking earnestly to Lucy, as she listens deeply engrossed in what he is saying. 168

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, looking out of the window. He frowns. What can thi stranger be talking about to her? 169

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James. He turns, says something, then speaks sharply 170

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James and Hibbs, as Hibbs, recalled to himself, turns suddenly and starts again to take Sir James' dictation. 171

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke and Lucy, as he stops talking and they look into ea other's eyes. Then she says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I do trust you -- in anything!" BACK TO SCENE: He bows his head a little. Then, with girl impulsiveness, she tells him:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "I think you're wonderful!" BACK TO SCENE: She finishes title, looking at him with ey radiant with admiration. 172

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, writing in his note book at window, as he turns, taking a glance at the window. He sees: 173

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke and Lucy as she reaches up in sudden impulsiveness and kisses him on the cheek. 174

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James and Hibbs, as Sir James has recalled his secretary, who is staring out the window. Hibbs is now ve plainly perturbed. 175

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke and Lucy, as Lucy nods to some things he is telling her, then turns and runs out of scene toward the house. 176

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke, looking off after her. Fondly he puts his hand to his cheek where she had kissed him and we have a feeling that if his life were to be lived over again he would hav romance in it -- romance with a girl not unlike Miss Lucy Balfour. 177

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James, finishing letter, dismisses Hibbs, who exits t the hall. 178

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, coming out of music room, meets Lucy, coming in th front door. He stops her, tells her that she saw her kiss the guest, wanting to know what she means. 179

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs and Lucy, as he angrily demands of her an explanati She is much perturbed. She says finally:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "I can't tell you -- please don't ask me--"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy, as she finishes title, much worried, as though she would like very much to tell if she could. 181

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, frowning his displeasure at her. 182

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy, looking out of scene at him, anxiously. Finally, wi a thought, she says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "I'm going to Sir James -- NOW -- and tell him that we love each other--"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy and Hibbs, as she finishes title. He can only stare her for a moment. "Are you?" he says breathlessly. Everything must be all right if that is what she is going do. "Yes," she tells him, and turns and goes into the mus room. He stands staring after her, then goes down the hal a little way. 184

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James is pacing the floor, deep in thought, as Lucy comes in. She is about to say something to him, but he stops her, then indicates a settee. We have the feeling that he is going to tell her about her father and doesn't quite know how to go about it. He turns, finally, and sit down beside her. 185

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy and Sir James, on settee, as he sits down. A tremulo excitement is upon Lucy now that the moment has come for to tell him of her love for Hibbs. Now the problem of how begin has become her problem. Sir James sits, deeply thoughtful, staring at the floor. She turns to him and is  about to tell him in a rush when he looks up and says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Lucy, there is something I have to tell you-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK TO SCENE: He pauses. She looks at him, big-eyed, inguiringly. He clears his throat and goes on:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: “Ever since you were a little girl, Lucy, I've waited--"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James as he pauses, hesitating-- 187

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy staring at him big-eyed, breathlessly, beginning to guess the truth. 188

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James, as he turns to her, a life long love for her i his eyes and says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "It may seem a strange time to speak, Lucy, but--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James and Lucy as he pauses, then says fervently:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "I love you, Lucy -- I want you to marry me

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK TO SCENE: He finishes title, taking her hands gently Lucy, looking at him aghast, at the devotion in his eyes, knows that this is no time to tell him. So she falters:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "I--I must have time-- to--to think it over--" BACK TO SCENE: He nods gravely, patting her hand gently.  She starts to draw away, to rise. 190

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy, rising, stands for a moment, uncertainly. Sir James rises, turns toward her. Suddenly Lucy bursts into a sob and runs from the room. Sir James takes a step after her and stops, thinking. 191

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs is waiting in the hall as Lucy comes out. Burke is coming in the front door. Hibbs glares at him as Lucy, sobbing a little, goes to Hibbs. Burke turns in at the library. Hibbs and Lucy go out to the veranda. 192

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke, coming in, stands for a moment, then steps over to the desk and picks up one of the volumes on vampires. Wit this in his hand, he goes over to a chair by the window, where the sunlight is coming in and sits down. 193

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy and Hibbs, as she tells him what happened. Hibbs get over: "I'll go to him, tell him." She holds his arm. "No, no you can't." 194

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke, turning and looking out of the window. Then, with little sigh for his advancing age and his incapacity for romance, he takes out his glasses, puts them on and start to read from the book. After a moment, he glances up from the book into the room. 195

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James has come into the library. Burke, looking up, tells him he has been reading something about protective measures. He shows a passage in the book to Sir James:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page in Old English: A wreath of tube-roses at the window, a sword across the door will make it impossible for the vampyr to enter a sleeping room at night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke, Sir James, Hibbs and Lucy. Hibbs is reading from o of the ancient books at a table. Lucy is placing a wreath of tube-roses at the window. There is a sword on the tabl Lucy turns and tells them: "That's done," coming down to the table. Hibbs, picking up the sword and the book, rise He and Burke start toward the door. Sir James turns to sa good night to Lucy. 197

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James saying good night to Lucy, saying it tenderly, his devotion in his eyes. 198

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs and Burke at the open door, waiting. It is evident that Hibbs, who is looking back, sees Sir James' tenderne his love for Lucy. Hibbs is troubled. 199

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James and Lucy, as he bends over and kisses her gentl with a fatherly kiss, and turns and exits. Lucy turns awa back into the room with bowed head. 200

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the door, as Sir James comes in, going out of the door after Burke. Hibbs looks back in the room toward Lucy, troubled, his love in his eyes, then turns and goes out, starting to close the door behind him. 201

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside door to Lucy's room, as Sir James says good night to Burke in f£.g., while Hibbs fastens the sword to the d over the keyhole. Hibbs turns to Burke and they exit together toward Hibbs' room. 202

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At door to Hibbs' room, as Burke and Hibbs come in. Hibbs opens the door and turns to say good night. Burke indicat that he would like to talk to him. Hibbs says "Come in," and they exit to Hibbs' room. 203

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is dark as Hibbs and Burke come in. There is a shaft of moonlight through a window upon the bed. Hibbs switches on the electric light. They go over and sit on t bed. 204

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men as they sit on the bed. Burke says to him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Now about you and Miss Lucy's brother, Harry--" BACK TO SCENE: Hibbs turns sharply, staring at Burke. Bur goes on regardless:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "You didn't like each other very much did you?" BACK TO SCENE: Hibbs is about to resent this question, bu there is a force in Burke's direct gaze that he cannot resist. So, after a moment, he answers:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "He objected to my caring for Lucy. He thought I wasn't good enough for her--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, as he finishes title, looking out of scene at Burk 206

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke staring steadily at him, an intense light in his ey 207

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, unable to stand unflinching the direct gaze, looks away, looks down at his wristwatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WRISTWATCH. Time -- 10:13 BACK TO SCENE: He looks up again at Burke. 208

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke, with eyes lighted so that they seem to dart fire. The eyes start now to revolve, slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The electric light is out. Burke is lying on the bed in t shaft of moonlight, asleep. He stirs a little, turns over into the shadow. A dim figure back to the camera, tips i leaning over the bed. Burke turns back again into the lig The figure withdraws. Burke sits up, suddenly staring off scene, whips up a pistol from the bed and fires out of scene. (Burke wears pajama jacket. Otherwise, he is completely dressed.) 210

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dim figure back to camera, disappearing through the ope door. 211

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At bed, as Burke leaps to his feet, pistol in hand, and rushes out of scene. 212

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hall is empty. Burke, rushing out from Hibbs' room, pistol in hand, stops, looking around. The door to Sir James' room is suddenly thrown open and Sir James rushes out, demanding: "What is it? What's the matter?" Burke go quickly down to him. 213

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James, as Burke comes in. Sir James demanding "What happened?" Sir James is in a bathrobe, which he now ties around him, as though he had been suddenly awakened and h slipped it on very hurriedly before rushing out. Burke tells him about something that came into the room, where was sleeping. Sir James is aghast. Burke to calm him, say

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: “Probably my imagination, Sir James. Go back to bed." BACK TO SCENE: Burke opens the door to Sir James and ushe Sir James in. He closes the door, turns, with pistol read and exits from scene, down the hall. 214

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke, coming in, looking at the floor, suddenly kneels t the floor. 215

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke, kneeling on floor, inspecting the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some drops of blood on floor. BACK TO SCENE: Burke puts his finger in one of the drops  and holds it up. Fresh blood. He thinks a moment, then starts to rise. 216

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke, rising, exits through the open door back to Hibbs’ room. 217

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke, coming in from hall, switches on the light. It is now seen that he has Hibbs in a hypnotic trance, lying covered by a blanket on a couch in a corner. Burke goes over, looks at Hibbs a moment, then straightens out the b that he had himself occupied, takes off his pajama jacket and put on his coat. Then he steps over, speaks to Hibbs. Hibbs rises and goes over to the bed and sits on it, just as he was sitting before the last fade out. Burke sits down beside him. 218

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke and Hibbs are on the bed as Burke looks at him with piercing eyes. Hibbs is staring straight ahead of him. No Burke speaks to him sharply. Hibbs starts, and a transformation takes place. He comes out of the hypnotic trance, realizes his surroundings, looks at Burke and say

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "I must have fallen asleep." BACK TO SCENE: Burke nods "yes" and then gets over to him that he'd better be getting to bed. Saying this Burke ris 219

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke, rising, says good night and goes out the door. Hib still a little dazed, rubs his eyes, gets up and goes ove to a dresser. 220

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs at the dresser. He stands there for a moment thinki He stifles a yawn. Then he looks at his wristwatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU wristwatch Time: 2:30 BACK TO SCENE: Hibbs is puzzled. He must have slept hours That's queer. He stands thinking a moment, then dismisses the problem with a shrug and reaches into a drawer of the dresser and gets out a photograph. He looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Photograph of Lucy. BACK TO SCENE: Hibbs looks at the picture fondly, greatly troubled. He decides to see if she is all right. He turns puts the picture back into the drawer and starts out. 221

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, going softly, but quickly, out the door. 222

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, coming out of his door, tiptoes quickly over to th door to Lucy's room. 223

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Lucy's door, as Hibbs comes in. The sword has gone fro its place over the keyhole where Hibbs himself placed it. This he notices now with a start of alarm. He looks down see if it has fallen. No sword. In genuine anxiety now, h knocks on the door and calls:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Lucy!" BACK TO SCENE: He waits. No answer. He knocks harder. He calls again, more loudly. Frantic, he tries the door, banging it, calling to her in a loud voice. He throws his shoulder against the door. It gives a little. 224

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking in doors to Sir James' and Burke's rooms. Both doo open and Burke and Sir James appear. They start forward, excitement. (Both are fully dressed.) 225

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs throwing his weight against the door. It crashes op as Burke and Sir James come into scene. Hibbs rushes into the room. 226

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room in darkness, Hibbs rushing in. Sir James and Bur follow. Burke switches on the light. The room is empty. Hibbs rushes to the dressing room door, looks in there, turns back: "Empty!" 227

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The great room downstairs. The Stranger, the man identifi as Roger Balfour, is sitting in the chair at the table. Sitting with his back to the camera is the Man in the Beaver Hat. Lucy, in a white thin negligee, is being led  into the room by the Bat Girl. She starts toward the Stranger at the table with uncertain steps, then stops. 228

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy, staring out of scene, her lips trembling. 229

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stranger at the table, looking out of scene at her wi large, spectral eyes, a bullet wound in his temple, the pallor of death on his face. 230

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of them, motionless for a few feet. Then Lucy starts suddenly forward, kneeling at the Stranger's feet. 231

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stranger, looking down at her with eyes of pity, sayi no word, 232

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy, looking up tremulously. When she raises her eyes, a if in a prayer, and says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: “Father! Father! I'm doing this for you!" BACK TO SCENE: She finishes title. 233

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stranger puts his hand on Lucy's head, the Bat Girl a one side, the Man in the Beaver Hat sitting watching them The whole effect is strange, fantastic, creepy. 234

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three men, Burke, Sir James, Hibbs. Burke is at the open window, looking out, as though for something he migh be expecting. Hibbs is talking wildly to Sir James. He cries out:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: “They're vampyrs, I tell you, and I'm going to destroy them -- the way the book says--" BACK TO SCENE: He finishes title and turns and runs madly out of the scene, for the time being a maniac. Burke turn quickly down from the window to Sir James, indicates off  and says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "They're coming!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke and Sir James, as Burke finishes title, indicating off toward the window. "Who?" gasps Sir James in his astonishment. Burke replies quickly, his manner brisk and business like.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: “The Scotland Yard men you wrote for." BACK TO SCENE: He finishes title. Sir James' relief is prodigious. They start out toward the door. 236

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An English car, turning in at the gate, drives toward the house. 237

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, feverishly fingering the pages of the ancient book until he finds what he wants, reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page in old English: The one certain method, which never fails, is to drive a hickory stake through the heart of the vampyr. BACK TO SCENE: Hibbs looks up, looks wildly around the ro as though there might be a hickory stake there somewhere, then turns and runs out the door. 238

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke, opening the door, admitting four burly Scotland Ya men. With Sir James, they all exit to the library. 239

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Smithson and the other servants are huddled together scared half to death. They turn and scream as the door is flung open and Hibbs, wild-eyed and breathless, bursts in the room. Seeing who it is they subside. He tells them th he has got to have an ax and a hickory stake. One of the men hands him a hand-ax from the wood box by the stove. looks at a chair -- it isn't hickory. Wildly, he turns to the table, inspecting it. With the ax he starts to knock one of the legs off the table. 240

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James sitting at the desk, the four Scotland Yard men and Burke standing, as Burke is crisply telling them of t extraordinary events. They listen like good soldiers, but solid as they are, they cannot escape a gasp or two of surprise. 241

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, finishing sharpening the end of a table leg to a point. With this in one hand and the ax in the other, he runs out the back door. Miss Smithson slams it after him and nervously fixes the latch. 242

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Smithson nervously fixing the latch. Her hand shakes so that she has to make two or three attempts before she gets it. Then she turns, sinks back against the door, breathing deeply, her eyes bulging. Her whole attitude conveys that she thinks she had a narrow escape while the door was open. 243

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke turns from the four Scotland Yard men to Sir James the desk, drawing up a chair to the end of the desk so th they are facing each other. 244

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke and Sir James, as Burke sits down, facing Sir James He studies Sir James for a moment, then says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Have you got a gun?" BACK TO SCENE: For answer, Sir James reaches into a drawe of the desk and takes out a large Army revolver. Burke looks at it and puts it aside, saying:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "You've got to have one you can be sure will shoot."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group, as Burke finishes title, rising and turning t the four Scotland Yard men. One of them takes an automati pistol from his pocket and hands it to Burke. Burke gives this to Sir James and tells him to put it in his pocket. Sir James does so. Burke starts to sit down again. 246

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke and Sir James, as Burke sits down, facing Sir James Burke starts to talk to him and as he talks his eyes take on an intense piercing quality. He stops talking, holding Sir James' gaze with his own for a few feet while neither man moves a muscle. Then Burke turns easily away, leaning back for a moment, relaxed. James continues to sit without moving. Burke then reaches over and picks up a desk clock. He turns the hands back a sets it down on the desk again. Sir James looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DESK CLOCK Time: 8:15 BACK TO SCENE: Sir James looks up from the clock. Burke tells him:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "At 8:25, leave here and come to the side door of Balfour House." BACK TO SCENE: He finishes title, studying Sir James for moment, and then rises. 247

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke, rising, pays no further attention to Sir James, wh sits staring at the clock. With a gesture to the men to follow, Burke exits briskly from the library. The four Scotland Yard men go out after him. 248

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With gate in f.g., as Hibbs, carrying his stake and ax, comes in, stops for a moment, looking in toward the house and all around the garden, then starts in toward the hous slipping from clump to clump of shrubbery. 249

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, coming behind a clump of shrubbery, drops down suddenly, as though hearing something off toward the hous 250

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Door to the side veranda, as it starts slowly to open. Lucy appears in the doorway, behind her the ominous figu of the Stranger, with face so white and the bullet wound his temple. She stops in the doorway. He stops. 251

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, in the clump of brush, as he cautiously raises himself and looks off. He stares, suddenly seeing: 252

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy standing in the doorway, looking out into the night. The Stranger directly behind her. She does not move. But the Stranger takes a step closer to her and leans over wi his face Close to hers. 253

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy and the Stranger, as his ghastly face comes very clo to hers. Still she does not move, but looks off into the night. 254

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLASH Hibbs staring off. His grip tightens on his stake a ax, and the look in his eyes is terrible to see. 255

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy and the Stranger, with his face just behind hers and very close to her. He whispers in her ear.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Tell him to go, Lucy. Only harm can come to him here." BACK TO SCENE: He finishes title. Lucy nods solemnly. 256

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLASH of Hibbs staring. He starts forward. 257

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stranger draws back quickly into the room as Lucy ste out onto the veranda. The Stranger closes the door. Hibbs comes in below her, on the ground, calling: "Lucy! Lucy!" 258

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, looking up at her, saying her name, softly but wit tragic earnestness. 259

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy, looking down at him, a large pity in her eyes, as s  tells him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK TO SCENE: She finishes title. 260

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, staring up at her, saying the same. "Lucy! Lucy!" 261

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and the Bat Girl, in her black dress, with her face so white, comes out softly to Lucy, puts an arm around her shoulder and slowly starts back into the house with her. 262

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, he can only stare at this -- powerless for the moment to act. His eyes follow them to the door. 263

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy and the Bat Girl going slowly through the door. It closes behind them. 264

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, standing motionless, staring after them as one fro whom the power to move had been taken. Suddenly he starts out through the brush, along the side of the house. 265

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James, sitting just as we left him staring at the des clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DESK CLOCK Time 8:25 BACK TO SCENE: Sir James starts to rise. 266

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James, rising, goes directly out the door. 267

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The butler is waiting with Sir James' hat and stick, very evidently by arrangement with Burke. Sir James, coming ou from the library, takes his hat and stick from the butler saying:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I am going over to call upon my old friend Roger Balfour." BACK TO SCENE: The butler bows solemnly to this, holding the door open while Sir James goes out. 268

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke slipping in a back door of the house. 269

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, coming cautiously around a corner of the house, looking up toward the windows. 270

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man with Beaver Hat, back to camera, Burke comes in. The Man with the Beaver Hat turns and is now seen to be a different person from the man that rented the house. Without a word he whips off the Inverness coat and hat an hands them to Burke. Burke starts to make himself up as t other character -- The Man in the Beaver Hat, as we first saw him face to face, when he rented the house. 271

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, climbing up a side of the house to look in through window. He sees: 272

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy and the Bat Girl alone in the great room. The Bat Gi is starting to undo Lucy's dress at the neck. 273

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, looking in through the broken window. To him, this can mean only one thing -- the girl in black is a vampyr -- she is going to put those sharp teeth in Lucy's throat -- | With the stake, he smashes at the window. 274

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy and the Bat Girl, as they wheel, staring off toward the window. 275

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs plunging in through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Great Room, as the Bat Girl quickly rushes Lucy off behind some portieres. As Hibbs rushes in that direction, the three men of the Balfour House entourage leap out fr places of hiding and seize him. They have ropes and a gag 277

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, struggling in the grip of the three men. Hibbs is maniac and the struggle is brief but fierce. They wrench the stake and ax from him, hurling them to one side. They start to bind him. 278

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy and the Bat Girl behind portieres. The Bat Girl is holding her, telling her not to interfere. But Lucy must see. She pulls the portiere aside a little, looking out. 279

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three men and Hibbs. They have him on the floor, binding him tight, putting a gag in his mouth. 280

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy and the Bat Girl, behind the portieres. Lucy turns back, hiding her face with her hands. The Bat Girl, her manner business-like, starts again to undo Lucy's dress from the shoulder. 281

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the Great Room, as the three men carry Hibbs out of th room. As they exit, at the top of the stairs appears the Man in the Beaver Hat. He starts slowly down the stairs. 282

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With traveling camera, of the Man in the Beaver Hat as he comes slowly, with awful purpose in his eyes, down the steps. He stops at the landing, his eyes searching the room. 283

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Door or portiered exit through which Hibbs was taken by the three men. The three now reappear. They stop, looking off toward the stairs. 284

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man in the Beaver Hat, staring out of scene at them with piercing eyes. He gives an order. 285

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is sudden activity on the part of the three men. Th Stranger moves over to the table, fixing the chairs there in exactly the right position, then sitting down. (The bullet wound does not appear on his temple now, though w make no point of its not being there.) Another of the thr men slips on a butler's coat and takes up a position by t side door. The third man withdraws. The Man in the Beaver Hat, who has been watching this from the landing of the stairs, now comes down and views the setting, suggesting change or two, perhaps here and there. 286

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind portieres, as the Bat Girl finishes hooking up a simple little dress (the sort that would be worn by a gir of thirteen or so) on Lucy. Lucy's hair is now down, as a child would wear it. 287

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything appears to be to the satisfaction of the Man i the Beaver Hat now. He steps over to the portiere. 288

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At portieres, as the Man in the Beaver Hat speaks softly. Lucy appears through the portieres, looking now like a gi of thirteen, in her child's dress with her hair down. She looks at the Man in the Beaver Hat, unafraid. Gravely he nods. That is the way he wants her to appear. They start out from scene. 289

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James, coming in, turns at the gate, and without even looking up at the house or without faltering in the slightest, starts toward the veranda and side door. 290

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man in the Beaver Hat is coming down from the portier with Lucy. He places her at an end of the table and gives her a book to look at.

dialogues.speaker: EXT BALFOUR VERANDA, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: Sir James coming with unhesitating steps along the verand works the knocker on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All inside hear the knocker and turn. With a gesture, The Man in the Beaver Hat waves all out of the room except th Stranger and Lucy at the table and the man in the butler' coat. Then he (the Man in the Beaver Hat) ducks quickly behind the portieres. The butler goes to the door. 293

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At door, as the butler opens it and Sir James steps in, h hands his hat and stick to the butler with a grave nod an exits into the room.  294

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stranger and Lucy at the table. The Stranger says: "Good evening, James" Lucy gets up and comes to Sir James in f£.g. He turns and puts his arm around her saying:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "My! My! What a big girl you're getting to be, Lucy."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James and Lucy, as he finishes title, stroking her hair, looking down at her fondly. 296

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At portieres, as they part slightly and the Man in the Beaver Hat peers out with piercing eyes. 297

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
