dialogues.text: Sir James, the Stranger and Lucy, as Sir James holds Lucy off at arm's length, looking at her, at the sweet girlhoo of her. The Stranger watches them morosely. Sir James tur to him says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "you seem despondent, Roger." BACK TO SCENE: The Stranger nods. Lucy steps quickly, impetuously over to him, putting an arm around him. 298

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy and the Stranger, as she puts her arm over him, lovingly, kissing him on the forehead. He pats her hand, tells her it's nothing. 299

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James, watching them, his eyes narrowing as he looks, a little. 300

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy and the Stranger, as he tells her, gently:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "It's getting late, Lucy -- say good night to Sir James."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three of them as the Stranger finishes title. Lucy gives him a good night kiss, then steps over to Sir James holding up her lips to him. Sir James kisses her and she runs out of scene. Sir James stands looking off after her The Stranger watches him sullenly. Sir James turns back n to the Stranger, drawing up the chair, and sitting down a the table, facing him. 302

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man in the Beaver Hat peering through the portieres. parts them a little more, bringing his whole face into vi -- the face with the pallor of death, as expressionless a mask. 303

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James and the Stranger at the table. Sir James leans over and says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "You may as well understand, Roger, that as soon as she comes of age, I mean to have her." BACK TO SCENE: The Stranger pounds his fist on the table and says: "No, by God!" They look straight into each other's eyes for a moment, then the Stranger says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "I trusted you, James Hamlin, and you've stolen from me vight and left."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men, as the Stranger, finishing the title, starts to rise. Before he can do so, Sir James has leaped to his feet and drawn his pistol. They rush into a clinch, a struggle. 305

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At portieres, the Man in the Beaver Hat -- FLASH 306

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James and the Stranger, as the Stranger falls out of scene. Sir James stands with smoking pistol in his hand. stares down at him. He leans down out of scene. 307

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stranger on the floor as dead. Sir James leaning into scene with pistol in his hand. He takes out a handkerchie wipes off the handle of the pistol and puts it into the Stranger's right hand. He starts up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The body on the floor, Sir James backing away to the portieres behind which the Man in the Beaver Hat was hiding. 309

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At portieres as Sir James backs in. He is about to back through the portiere when two Scotland Yard men step out and grab him. The Man in the Beaver Hat comes out, steps to Sir James, facing him. 310

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man in the Beaver Hat and Sir James, as the man speak to him sharply. Sir James goes quickly through the transformation of coming out of a hypnotic trance. He stares at the Man in the Beaver Hat, saying dazedly:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "Have I been asleep?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James as he finishes title dazedly. 312

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man in the Beaver Hat, as he says, crisply:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "No, and neither have I."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of them as the Man in the Beaver Hat finishes tit and reaches over and rips up the sleeve of Sir James' coa The Man in the Beaver Hat says, dryly:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "I thought I clipped you one tonight."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man in the Beaver Hat, as he finishes title, and through his make-up comes an expression that is undeniabl that of Burke, the detective. 315

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James, staring at him, getting who he is slowly. He blurts out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of them, as Burke takes off his wig and bows: "At your service." 317

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stranger getting up from the floor, unhurt, inspectin the gun in his hand with a grin, exiting. 318

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bat Girl and the butler, with a trunk in f.g. plainly "Lunette, the Flying Woman, Theatre". She is packing the trunk. The man is taking down wires from the ceiling. She looks up at him and says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "It's back to the music ‘alls, Jimmy, me bye." BACK TO SCENE: He answers:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "And I'll sye this is the goofiest engigement we ever played." BACK TO SCENE: They go back to their work briskly. 319

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Great Room downstairs, as Sir James, on the orders of Burke, sits down at the table and starts to write a confession. Lucy and Hibbs, with Miss Smithson, come in the end of the table. The Scotland Yard men are at the bg 320

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke and Sir James, as Burke tells him crisply:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "A full confession, Sir James -- including the murder of young Harry Balfour." BACK TO SCENE: Burke finishes title and exits toward Lucy 321

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs, Lucy, Miss Smithson, as Burke comes in Miss Smithson laughs, saying:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: “That was sure a whopper, chief, you had me tell about the keyhole." BACK TO SCENE: Burke laughs, then turns to Hibbs and Lucy They are looking at him in wonder. Lucy is radiant. After moment, Burke taps Hibbs on the shoulder and says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "My advice to you, Mr. Hibbs, is -- stay away from vampires."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke, as he pauses, looking at Hibbs quizzically. 323

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibbs and Lucy, his arm about her, Hibbs looks a little foolish. 324

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke, as he says:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "I don't mean the kind of vampires you mean, either--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three of them as Burke finishes title, smiling dryly, and adding:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: "This is the twentieth century." BACK TO SCENE: He finishes title, the two looking at him wonder and admiration, as
